fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A homological \delta-functor is a sequence of additive functors T_n : {\mathcal{A}} \to {\mathcal{B}} between abelian categories, with the convention that T_n = 0 for n < 0. For every short exact sequence 0 \to X \to Y \to Z \to 0 in {\mathcal{A}}, we have a connecting map \delta_n : T_n(Z) \to T_{n-1}(X), such that this assignment is natural in the exact sequence.

Similarly, a cohomological \delta-functor can be defined with \delta^n : T^n(Z) \to T^{n+1}(X). Notice that cohomology does not imply contravariance here. These also have contravariant versions, by replacing {\mathcal{A}} with {\mathcal{A}}^{\textrm{op}}.
Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds.

fr:ul.fr:li: Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given two additive categories and a functor F : {\mathcal{C}} \to {\mathcal{D}} between them, the following are equivalent. In this case, we call the functor additive.

fr:ul.fr:li: The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom_{{\mathcal{C}}}(X, Y), i.e. it is an {\mathsf{Ab}}-enriched functor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel{\sim\,}{\to} F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel{\sim\,}{\to} F(X \times Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of F, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel{\sim\,}{\to} F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that F preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.

A short exact sequence is an exact sequence with all but three consecutive terms being zero. It is often written as 0 \to A \to B \to C \to 0. The short exact sequence describes how B is made up of a subobject A and a quotient C.

Given a cohomological \delta-functor T^\bullet, if each T^n for n > 0 is effaceable, then it is a universal \delta-functor. Dually, if a homological \delta-functor is coeffaceable, then it is universal.

Given an object X, consider the exact sequence given by effaceability 0 \longrightarrow X \longrightarrow I \longrightarrow Y \longrightarrow 0. Then we have a long exact sequence 0 \to T^0 X \to T^0 I \to T^0 Y \xrightarrow{\delta} T^1 X \xrightarrow{0} T^1 I. and the rest breaks into infinitely many short exact sequences 0 \to T^{n+1} I \to T^{n+1} Y \to T^{n+2} X \to 0.

For independence, we first prove that if two effacements X \to I, X \to I' are connected by a morphism I \to I', then the resulting transformations are equal. This is essentially the same as the proof of naturality, except \varphi is replaced with {\textrm{id}}. Now any two effacements are connected by a zigzag, since we can take the diagonal X \to I \times I' and project out.

The \delta-functors between two abelian categories form a displayed category over the category of additive functors (or we can restrict it to right exact functors for homological \delta-functors). Under this setup, the definition of a universal \delta-functor can be expressed abstractly as a “relative” kind of terminal object or initial object. It is an object X displayed over x such that \hom_f (Y, X) = 1 for every Y and f.
Given two \delta-functors, a morphism between them is given by a sequence of natural transformations f_n : T_n \to S_n that additionally commutes with \delta.

Given a homological \delta-functor T_n, it is universal if given any other \delta-functor S_n and a natural transformation S_0 \to T_0 at degree 0, it can be uniquely extended to a morphism of \delta-functors. Dually, we can reverse the arrows to get the definition of a universal cohomological \delta-functor.
